content: Hey @tmandry =) you around today?
yep
shall we kick off the meeting? @WG-async-foundations

• Announcements
  • [nikomataskis] Update on vision doc
  • [tmandry] New issue triage
Any announcements?
or should we dive into the vision doc
I will note one thing
#81050 – the libs team is thinking of stabilizing ready! as pend!
I saw that
funny name, but I don't have a better suggestion :)
I bikeshod the name ready! because it was easy to confuse with futures::future::ready
yeah, I kind of like it though
yeah, it's cute
although
i like that it's a verb, but I don't ... understand it as a verb
I can't put my finger on what I mean
I guess there's a reason that "to be pending" is not a verb :)
it's not a commonly used verb
I feel like the "thing that is happening" is like wait_if_not_ready?
to pend or not to pend, that is the question
anyway, I guess the bike-shedding would be better done on thread, but I'm glad you reminded me of it...
uh oh :)
I'll probably just stay out of it :)
ok, shall we move to vision doc? @triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
ok
vision doc
So I just did a pass and merged a bunch of stories
we now have 8 shiny future stories, for example
and **38 status quo** stories!
including, I will say, my epic tale Alan extends an AWS service :)
technically this is the end of the brainstorming period
I am of mixed minds
on the one hand, I feel like we're ... "not done" when it comes to shiny future
on the other hand, I feel like the plan for post-brainstorming was that @tmandry and I would get to work on synthesizing and things
and I kind of think that's...an ok thing to happen now
how I'm imagining it is something like this
• we'll still accept PRs because why not
• we'll push to land the existing ones, imperfect or not
to be honest I still have stories I want to write
I think we need to kind of identify what we see as the biggest problems and the "broad strokes" of the solution -- e.g., something like 'enable portable libraries'

tmandry said:

to be honest I still have stories I want to write

i want you to write them!
and those are making progress, slowly

nikomatsakis said:

I think we need to kind of identify what we see as the biggest problems and the "broad strokes" of the solution -- e.g., something like 'enable portable libraries'

I have some drafts at this :)
since brainstorming period is technically over, i wonder if reviewers should perhaps have more of an eye toward incorporating details in new PRs into already existing stories
I've been emailing and meeting with various leaders and "prominent names" in the async space, which is what led to e.g. @Jon Gjengset's awesome story

Andrew Chin (eminence) said:

since brainstorming period is technically over, i wonder if reviewers should perhaps have more of an eye toward incorporating details in new PRs into already existing stories

not a bad idea

nikomatsakis said:

I think we need to kind of identify what we see as the biggest problems and the "broad strokes" of the solution -- e.g., something like 'enable portable libraries'

I guess what I'm saying is I'd like to produce a high-level outline of the final vision doc and shop it around for feedback
something else:
I was thinking how to approach shiny future
i feel like if we have the high-level goals ("portable across runtimes', "better cancellation', etc)
we might then solicit shiny future stories exploring those themes
like, ok, we know that's what we want to do, but how would we do it?
I kind of imagine having more direction and a goal might make it easier
and I could see running e.g. brainstorming sessions with a particular goal in mind
/me fin

(very minor point, but i'd like to start cross referencing status-quo stories with shiney future stories. for example, at the bottom of a status quo story, there would be a "to see how this story might play out in the future, click here, here, or here" link)
yeah, I tend to agree with all of that

Andrew Chin (eminence) said:

(very minor point, but i'd like to start cross referencing status-quo stories with shiney future stories. for example, at the bottom of a status quo story, there would be a "to see how this story might play out in the future, click here, here, or here" link)

love this
feels like we're writing a choose your own adventure novel for async :D
yeah cross-referencing would be great
oh
I was literally going to do that
I forgot about that completely!

https://twitter.com/b0rk/status/1382383203999219716?s=19

Yesterday I got the idea to make a choose-your-own-adventure game about debugging a computer networking problem, so I spent all morning on it today. Here's a very early draft: https://computer-mysteries.netlify.app/slow-website.html I'd love to know what folks think of this approach to learning debugging!

- 🔎Julia Evans🔍 (@b0rk)
I had started doing it after I saw that tweet
but I got distracting by life

https://twitter.com/b0rk/status/1382390228149764105

if you want to read the source for this, it's a Twine game -- Twine has really great documentation! i managed to learn it and make this game in maybe 6 hours. https://github.com/jvns/twine-stories/blob/main/slow-website.twee

- 🔎Julia Evans🔍 (@b0rk)
twine is cool :)
oh wow, that's clever
if somebody wanted to turn status quo stories to a twine game i would be your best friend forever
oh, i should add one other thing ...
... I'm planning on creating t-shirts for everyone that's been involved in the effort ...
(surprise!)
... so we should make sure our "acknowledgements" page is up to date ...
i think it's missing some people who attended writing sessions
also the script seemed to have some bugs
Is the rest up to date? I still need to fix the script
make sure your own name is there, @Stu :)
the rest is as up to date afaik
maybe I'll send out a tweet for folks to add themselves to the writing session list

https://twitter.com/nikomatsakis/status/1393254998138658816

I want to make sure that we thank everyone who participated in a @rustlang async vision doc writing session so far! Check this list and let me know if you are missing! https://rust-lang.github.io/wg-async-foundations/acknowledgments.html#-participating-in-an-writing-session (the other sections are auto-generated, though the script may have some bugs)

- Niko Matsakis (@nikomatsakis)
ok, so let's do this:

• officially close the brainstorming session, but note that we are still landing PRs
  • start working towards a "problems + solutions" list and getting feedback on it
  • hold some writing sessions focused on particular solutions next week?
I'm sure the best way to 'get feedback'
I'd like feedback on another point
i don't want to lose all these great stories
but i want the final doc to be consumable
i'm imagining that we wind up with a story kind of like the 'story of an AWS engineer'
maybe two or three of them
that knit together the other stories into a coherent theme

also, didn't you start writing (or actually write) a "meta story" that tried to tied all the status-quo stories together? does that need another pass to update with the latest set of status-quo stories?
we did, and it does
metanarrative
it is close to the form I am talking about, except it's not a story
The aws story is even closer, I think
anyway I was imagining maybe we'd have a section with all the stories that were submitted as well
sort of an archive?
in a way, it sounds like you're looking for some type of "executive summary", which can then use all the individual stories as "citations"
yes, I imagine something like this
that is, sentences in the story will link to a detailed write-up
I think this will require adapting the stories we have to be the right character etc
I also want to talk clearly about prioritization
which problems do we see as biggest and why
that's probably more the FAQ on the executive summary though
yep, makes sense to me
i'm still thinking about the characters
@rylev had an interesting suggestion for how he decides between them
(Barbara and Alan get the vast majority of the stories)

• alan for "things where you have to know, but once you know they're more of a papercut"
  • barbara for "things that are still hard no matter what"
yeah. I like how the characters are aligned to rust's core values.
(I wonder if the "language background" distracts from that a bit?)

nikomatsakis said:

yeah. I like how the characters are aligned to rust's core values.

er, what I left unsaid was, I like it, but I don't feel like we've evenly distributed much across them
interesting to think on why that is
i was about to ask if we should try to carve out some space for a 3rd character between Alan and Barbara... but i'm not sure how much that helps
I'm pondering the idea of just having the characters represent core "rust values"
and looking at the stories from that POV
e.g., 'is this a story about performance'
in practice, i think people reading the stories are going to identify mostly with what the characters are experiencing (not not so much their background)
I imagine the Fuchsia stories will feature Grace more
'about correctness and reliabiility'
I'm also trying to think about the characters being in use across many vision docs throughout the project
oh, side note, I want to mention the CTCFT meeting this Monday
async vision docs are on the agenda :)

nikomatsakis said:

e.g., 'is this a story about performance'

it might be interesting to see what this list of core rust values might look like
yes, I'll be there :)

Andrew Chin (eminence) said:

in practice, i think people reading the stories are going to identify mostly with what the characters are experiencing (not not so much their background)

I have not found the "language backgrond" to be a very useful facet
i agree thigns like "performance" are definitely more important to some people than others
@Andrew Chin (eminence) see also my "wip" doc on rust's guiding principles
interesting, I could see that
that said, I think rust's core value prop is fairly clear: performance, safety + reliability, productivity, and community
but things like "correctness and reliability" -- maybe most people will look at that and think "hmm, everyone wants those!"
everybody wants all of those :)
but to different amounts
I think the familiarity with Rust bit we have now does seem to help
yeah, that's true
new to rust or not new to rust is relevant
but like js vs java vs C++... less than I expected
in any case I'd be up for juggling the characters around a bit

nikomatsakis said:

but like js vs java vs C++... less than I expected

it may matter but not in the way we're bucketing them with the characters
yeah. I do wonder if when we compile the stories into a few "meta-narratives', it'll be clearer
I'm sort of assuming that:)
yeah
I think if I did this again I might even tell people to just write stories as themselves or something, idk
yeah. i suspect "rust works differently than [other language i know]" is important
I do like the point about combining stories where we can
I think that was one of the intentions behind the characters
I'd sort of like to preserve the fuchsia narrative, but maybe we can do that similarly to AWS but with linking to some existing stories if we can work them in
(once that narrative is written down I mean :)

I read a reddit post yday, might be helpful to visualise how people feel about rust coming from other languages, I think a story already exists for this.

https://www.reddit.com/r/rust/comments/nbiqhw/understanding_futures_and_async_in_rust/

tmandry said:

I'd sort of like to preserve the fuchsia narrative, but maybe we can do that similarly to AWS but with linking to some existing stories if we can work them in

I did some amount of linking from the AWS stories to pre-existing stories
but I ran out of time to do much more :)
I would very much like to see the Fuchsia narrative
maybe fuchsia, aws, et al are each their own meta-narrative, that we try to merge into one proto narrative or something
anyway, we can figure it out next week
I could see keeping those as distinc meta narratives
but it'll be easier to see if that makes sense when we have more than one :)
shall we move on?
i was just wondeing-- i guess we need to decide on action items
I think i'll make some updates to the webpage with the rough plan I noted above?
I don't want people to come to the How To vision page and it's just out of date
I'm going to change the :check: Now! to like :warning: Winding down
sounds good
that reminds me that I wanted to do awards
but we can discuss that later
you and I should schedule time to work on the outline next week
yep
I'll send an email :)
is that all? @triagebot end-topic

Does anyone have something to add on the current topic?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if not.
ok, great
issue triage
one today
Wrongly typing a collect with async streams causes confusing error messages alongside a cascade of unhelpful error messages #85132
fun
yeah :)
I guess this is inference giving up or something
yeah what's happening I tink is that
well, there's some query that requires types to be known
we should probably be suppressing those when the body had errors
I thin we could mentor this without too much difficulty
I wonder if we should make a special case error for async blocks in iterator combinators or something
side note: maybe we should generate -Ztreat-err-as-bug to take an argument
it'd be nice to be able to say "treat the Nth error as a bug" in this case
oh, it does :)
pretty sure I've done that before at least
I'd like the backtrace of " type inside async block must be known in this context" specifically
I wish you could use -Ztreat-err-as-bug from the playground
I.. might have time to look into this one, but I already have one on my backlog (hope to dig in to that today)
maybe the playground could accept args like that in some type of special comment (eg // rustc:-Ztreat-err-as-bug)
that would be nice
probably a security hole somehow :P

Andrew Chin (eminence) said:

maybe the playground could accept args like that in some type of special comment (eg // rustc:-Ztreat-err-as-bug)

cc @Jake Goulding
should this be on deck? I think it's borderline..
but it seems like something that people try to do
the only reason I see to put it on deck is that it might be easy to fix )
well and I could imagine it coming up a lot
yeah
okay, I guess I'll mark as triaged for now
does anyone else want to look into this one?
ok, I'll see if I can later today if not
that's the last item on our agenda
@triagebot end-meeting

Does anyone have something to bring up?
React with :working_on_it: if you have something to say.
React with :all_good: if you're ready to end the meeting.
alright. thanks everyone!

while the meeting was going on, I already fixed the contributors script and updated the list :)

There were many people missing
that's a lot more t-shirts
@nikomatsakis @Andrew Chin (eminence) a much-requested feature (in some form) https://github.com/integer32llc/rust-playground/issues/446

tmandry said:

that's a lot more t-shirts

that sounds like one of those good problems =)
